div1.p: Owen lists references to articles regarding spirochetes in Africa.

div1.head: Letter from William O. Owen to Joseph H. White, October 7, 1923
div1.opener:
C O P Y
October 7, 1923
Dr. Jos. White
My dear White:
div1.p:
I enclose the reference card to which I called your attention
today, the article in question was written at Brazzaville, Moyen-Congo, and
as I read it they passed the spirochetes through several generations of
guinea pigs producing hemoglobinuria in them.

They also found hemorrhagic icterus in the natives and black
water fever among the Europeans at the same time and that the one protected
from an attack of the other.

As you know I am engaged in Medical Research work in the libraries
of Washington, D.C. I can often be of assistance to those who are writing by
getting out the books which they want, and looking them up when they do not
know the reference.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, (Signed) W. O. Owen Présence de spirochètes dans le sang d'européens atteints de
fièbre bilieuse hémoglobinurique Le probleme étiologique de cette
spirochétose
A preliminary note to the Academy of Science, meeting of October
9, 1922
Bulletin de la Societe de Pathologie exotique 1922, xv, 699-722
see also 385-387
385 is perhaps more interesting to you than the second article
See also vol xvi No 3 14th of March 1923 page 184 193
(Yellow fever?) Bed Bug transmission, to guinea pigs
Vol xvi, no 4 page 238-241 reports a case or so of a spiro-
chetosis resembling clinically yellow fever in Upper Ivory Coast at
Darakolondougou
See also Vol xvi, No 5 297 May 9, 1923 a new case
